explosives.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified into Division 2.3 and Class 8 (UN#1076) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

gases_under_pressure.rationale: The boiling point is 8degC (ICSC (2004)), and the critical temperature is 182degC (HSDB (2006)) - i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.3 and Class 8 (UN#1076) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

organic_peroxides.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to gas substances are not available

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Based on human LC50 (inhalation of gas) value of 2ppm (4 hours: converted from 170 min), representing the two testing data, rat LC50 of 5.58ppm (4 hours) (CERI Hazard Data 2000-51 (2001)) and human LC50 of 3ppm (170 min).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "gas" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its vapour is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "gas" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its dust/mist is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale:
Based on the description in EHC 193 (1997): "Dermal contact with high concentrations of the substance causes irritation of the skin."
There have been reports of human health effects (EHC 193 (1997) and IRIS (2006)): "Skin contact with phosgene has been known to cause severe skin burns in humans. Vapor contact with moist or wet skin can lead to irritation and erythema."

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the descriptions of human health effects (CERI Hazard Data 2000-51 (2001), MOE Risk Assessment vol. 4 (2004) and EHC 193 (1997), ACGIH (7th, 2001)): "The substance has a strong irritancy potential, showing irritation of eyes and nose at 3ppm or higher. Accidental eye spillage of the substance results in severe damage to the eye," "eye irritation and burning sensation." The substance is thus considered a strong irritant.

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Classification not possible Skin sensitizer: Classification not possible
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: No data available Skin sensitizer: No data available

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, and negative data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests), described in IRIS (2006).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Classification not possible based on expert judgment, given the absence of existing classification.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "abnormalities observed mainly in the lung," "dyspnea and collapse," "brain damage is considered secondary to phosgene-related hypoxemia and low blood pressure" (IRIS (2005)), "headache, nausea, coughing, dyspnea, fatigue, pharyngalgia, chest tightness, chest pain and fever were observed in human subjects, 7 of whom developed pulmonary edema" (EHC 194 (1997)). Also based on the evidence from animal studies including "damage to the alveolar cells (type 1)," "accumulation of monoblasts in the bronchial branches and alveolar wall" (EHC 193 (1997)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: The effects on humans are reported as follows; "25 showed x-ray and clinical evidence of pneumonitis", "in two of these cases, bronchitis due to phosgene poisoning had been reported"(EHC 193 (1997)), "rapid, shallow breathing, high minute volume and low oxygen extract" (IRIS (2005)). In animal studies, "GPD activity increase, alveolar cell hyperplasia, macrophages with vacuolated cytopla" (EHC 193 (1997)), "interstitial thickening of the alveolus, inflammatory cell influx to terminal bronchiole/alveolus, increased collagen staining of terminal bronchiole/peribronchiolar" (IRIS (2005)) were reported. Based on these effects, the respiratory organs are considered to be the target organs. And these effects were observed within the guidance values for Category 1 in the repeated-dose study. Therefore, the substance was classified as Category 1 (respiratory organs).
